column3: is a first-magnitude artesian spring formation in Marion County
column6: several miles north of the city of Dunnellon.  Rainbow Springs is the focal point of Rainbow Springs State Park.  The spring formation is the fourth-largest in Florida
column7: and produces over 490 million gallons of water daily.  Rainbow Springs forms the headwaters of the Rainbow River
column8: which empties into the Withlacoochee River.

column1: Rainbow Springs was known as Wekiwa Creek by the Seminole Indians.
It was known as Blue Spring until the 1930s
column2: when the site was developed as a tourist attraction and the promoter sought a more distinctive name (there are several other springs in Florida named "Wekiwa" and "Blue"). To compete with the "glass bottom boats" of nearby Silver Springs
column4: submarine tours were given of the springs. As for some other Florida springs
column6: "mermaid shows" were an attraction in the 1950s. The tourist attraction was forced to close in the 1970s at Rainbow Springs but still goes on daily at Weeki Wachee Springs.

column1: The entire Rainbow River was designated as a Registered Natural Landmark in 1972
column3: and an "Outstanding Florida Waterway" in 1987.  The land around the headwaters of the springs remained privately owned until 1990
column4: when the State of Florida acquired the springs and saved them from development. Much of the work to open Rainbow Springs State Park was done by volunteers from the community.
